content.json: # Azure ARC Enabled SQL Server Best Practice Assessment

## Log Analytics Workspace
### To review Best Practice Assessments you will need to point to the correct Log Analytics Workspace

parameters.name: ResourceGroupLA
parameters.label: LA Resource Group
parameters.query:
resourceContainers 
| where type == "microsoft.resources/subscriptions/resourcegroups"
| join kind = inner (
    resources
    | where type == "microsoft.operationalinsights/workspaces"
    | distinct resourceGroup, subscriptionId
) on resourceGroup, subscriptionId
| project resourceGroup
| order by resourceGroup asc

parameters.name: LogAnalytics
parameters.label: Log Analytics Workspace
parameters.query:
resources
| where tolower(type) == "microsoft.operationalinsights/workspaces"
| where resourceGroup in ({ResourceGroupLA})
| project AffectedResource=id, resourceGroup

content.json: ## ARC SQL Best Practice Assessment Results

parameters.name: ResourceGroup
parameters.label: Resource Group
parameters.query:
resourceContainers 
| where type == "microsoft.resources/subscriptions/resourcegroups"
| join kind = inner (
    resources
    | where tolower(type) == "microsoft.hybridcompute/machines"
    | distinct resourceGroup, subscriptionId
) on resourceGroup, subscriptionId
| project resourceGroup
| order by resourceGroup asc

parameters.name: Server
parameters.label: ARC Enabled Server
parameters.query:
resources
| where type =~ "microsoft.hybridcompute/machines"
| where resourceGroup in ({ResourceGroup})
| project machineId = tolower(tostring(id)), Server = name
| join kind = inner (
    resources
    | where type =~ "microsoft.azurearcdata/sqlserverinstances"
    | extend machineId = tolower(tostring(properties.containerResourceId))
    | project machineId, name
) on machineId
| distinct machineId, Server

parameters.name: SQLServer
parameters.label: SQL Server
parameters.query:
resources
| where type =~ "microsoft.hybridcompute/machines"
| where tolower(tostring(id)) in ({Server})
| parse id with * 'machines/' Server
| where Server contains "{ServerSearch}"
| project machineId = tolower(tostring(id))
| join kind = inner (
    resources
    | where type =~ "microsoft.azurearcdata/sqlserverinstances"
    | extend machineId = tolower(tostring(properties.containerResourceId))
    | project SqlId = tolower(tostring(id)), machineId, name
) on machineId
| project SqlId, SQLServer = name

"FullBackup","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Microsoft is responsible for the availability of the SQL MI and Azure SQL DB that includes Recovery Point Objective and Recovery time Objective. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/database/business-continuity-high-availability-disaster-recover-hadr-overview?view=azuresql#rto-and-rpo```,```Category Description
We recommend that full backups are turned on as per your RPO and RTO.

Category Description Details
A full database backup backs up the whole database. This includes part of the transaction log so that the full database can be recovered after a full database backup is restored. Full database backups represent the database at the time the backup finished.

Category Recommendation
Azure SQL Database and Azure SQL Managed Instance automated backups create:
 Full backups every week.
 Differential backups every 12 or 24 hours.
 Transaction log backups approximately every 10 minutes.

Reference Links
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/relational-databases/backup-restore/full-database-backups-sql-server?view=sql-server-ver16
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/automated-backups-overview?view=azuresql```,```https://docs.microsoft.com/sql/relational-databases/statistics/statistics#CreateStatistics```,
"OutdatedTranLogBackup","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Azure SQL PaaS provides completely managed and automated SQL Server database engine backups. These backups enable database restore to a specific point in time within the configured retention period, up to 35 days. However, if your data protection rules require that your backups be available for an extended time (up to 10 years). The storage for the backups are managed by Microsoft based on the customer defined retention policy.```,```Category Description
We recommend that transactional backups are turned on as per your RPO and RTO.

Category Description Details
Independent of the database backups, the database administrator backs up the transaction log at frequent intervals. For a given type of backup, the optimal interval depends on factors such as the importance of the data, the size of the database, and the workload of the server.

"VLFCount","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost```,```Category Description
Update transaction log settings to reduce number of VLFs. 

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  The SQL Server Database Engine divides each physical log file internally into a number of virtual log files (VLFs). Virtual log files have no fixed size, and there is no fixed number of virtual log files for a physical log file. The Database Engine chooses the size of the virtual log files dynamically while it is creating or extending log files. The Database Engine tries to maintain a small number of virtual files. The size of the virtual files after a log file has been extended is the sum of the size of the existing log and the size of the new file increment. The size or number of virtual log files cannot be configured or set by administrators. If the log files grow to a large size in many small increments, they will have many virtual log files. This can slow down database startup and also log backup and restore operations. Conversely, if the log files are set to a large size with few or just one increment, they will have few very large virtual log files. We recommend that you assign log files a size value close to the final size required, using the required increments to achieve optimal VLF distribution, and also have a relatively large growth_increment value.

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Log backups and Instance startup are managed by Microsoft. The transaction logs are optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost.
Reference Links
1.https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/database/scale-resources?view=azuresql

"PowerPlanSchemeNotRecommended","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost```,```Category Description
Switch Server Plan to High Performance

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  In some cases you may experience degraded overall performance on a Windows Server 2008 R2 or later machine when running with the default (Balanced) power plan. The issue may occur irrespective of platform and may be exhibited on both native and virtual environments. The degraded performance may increase the average response time for some tasks and cause performance issues with CPU-intensive applications. Please note that you may not notice performance issues while performing simple operations. However, applications or scripts that intensively use resources (primarily processor and memory) may exhibit the problem. To work around the performance degradation issue, you can switch to the High Performance power plan.  However, this will disable dynamic performance scaling on the platform. Depending on the environment, if the platform is always under a heavy load, then this is a viable solution.

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Azure SQL DB and MI are fully managed cloud services. The compute is optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost. No manual intervention needed

Set Priority Boost option to default value

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  The 'priority boost' option used to specify whether Microsoft SQL Server should run at a higher scheduling priority than other processes on the same computer. If this option is set to 1, SQL Server runs at a priority base of '13' scheduler. The default is '0', which is a priority base of '7'.

Category recommendation

"QueryWaitNotDefault","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Increasing query wait time is not recommended. The query wait time for SQL MI and SQL DB has been configured considering the potential impact of locks and deadlock. If there is query timeout because of resource constraints, we highly recommend tuning the query or scaling resources attached to the database.```,```Category Description
Set Query wait time 

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  Memory-intensive queries (such as those involving sorting and hashing) are queued when there is not enough memory available to run the query. The query wait option specifies the time, in seconds (from 0 through 2147483647), that a query waits for resources before it times out. The default value for this option is -1. This means the time-out is calculated as 25 times the estimated query cost.

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Increasing query wait time is not recommended. The query wait time for SQL MI and SQL DB has been configured considering the potential impact of locks and deadlock. If there is query timeout because of resource constraints, we highly recommend tuning the query or scaling resources attached to the database.
Reference Links

Category recommendation

"ErrorLog605","Migration/Upgrade","0","0","0",```Minimum of three identical, consistent and synchronous copies of the disks are maintained in Azure. During disk corruption, the Azure SQL service will switch over to the healthy disk.```,```Category Description
Attempt to fetch a logical page failed. This error generally signifies page or allocation corruption, and often is caused by hardware or disk device driver failure.
Category Description Details
-  ERROR:  This error generally signifies page or allocation corruption in the specified database. SQL Server detects corruption when reading pages belonging to a table either by following the page linkages or by using the Index Allocation Map (IAM). All pages allocated to a table must belong to one of the allocation units associated with the table. If the allocation unit ID contained in the page header does not match an allocation unit ID associated with the table, this exception is raised. These errors are often caused by hardware or disk device driver failure. 

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Minimum of three identical, consistent and synchronous copies of the disks are maintained in Azure. During disk corruption, the Azure SQL service will switch over to the healthy disk.
   - Azure SQL VM - Minimum of three identical, consistent and synchronous copies of the disks are maintained in Azure. During disk corruption, the Azure VM will switch over to the healthy disk.

2.https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/disks-redundancy

"ErrorLog832","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Azure SQL PaaS is a scalable cloud database service that's always running on the patched OS with device drivers up to date. ```,```Category Description
A page that should have been constant has changed. This usually indicates a memory failure or other hardware or operating system corruption. An external factor has caused a database page to be modified outside the normal SQL Server engine code used to change database pages.

Category Description Details
-  ERROR:  An external factor has caused a database page to be modified outside the normal SQL Server engine code used to change database pages. 
The conditions could be:
- A thread running in the SQL Server process that incorrect writes on a database page. This is often referred to as a "scribbler"
- A hardware or operating system problem were the memory backing the database page is incorrect modified or damaged When SQL Server detects this behavior error 832 is raised.
Ensure all system drivers, Operating system updates, and hardware updates have been applied to our system.
Evaluate "external" DLLs loaded in SQL Server that could cause this problem including extended stored procedures, COM objects, or other DLLs that may be incorrectly modifying SQL Server memory reserved for database pages

 Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Azure SQL PaaS is a scalable cloud database service that's always running on the patched OS with device drivers up to date. Azure SQL DB and SQL MI does not support Extended Stored Procedures.

let machineCSV = ("{Server}");
let machineData = print machineCSV
| project machineArray = parse_csv(machineCSV)
| mv-expand machineId = machineArray
| project machineId = replace_string(tostring(machineId), "'", "")
| parse machineId with * 'machines/' Server
| where Server like "{ServerSearch}"
| join kind = inner (
    SqlAssessment_CL
    | extend
        machineId = tolower(_ResourceId),
        asmt = parse_csv(RawData),
        AsmtDate = format_datetime(TimeGenerated, 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm')
    | extend
        AsmtId=tostring(asmt[1]),
        SqlInstance = tostring(asmt[7])
    | where asmt[6] == "1"
    | distinct machineId, SqlInstance, AsmtDate, AsmtId
) on machineId
| project machineId, SqlInstance, AsmtDate, AsmtId;
let machineAsmtInfo = machineData
| join kind = inner (
    machineData
    | summarize AsmtDate = max(AsmtDate) by machineId, SqlInstance
) on machineId, SqlInstance, AsmtDate
| project machineId, SqlInstance, AsmtDate, AsmtId;
let machineSummary = SqlAssessment_CL
| extend
    machineId = tolower(_ResourceId),
    asmt = parse_csv(RawData)
| parse tostring(asmt[7]) with * ':' Database
| extend
    AsmtId=tostring(asmt[1]),
    CheckId=tostring(asmt[2]),
    SqlInstance = substring(tostring(asmt[7]), 0, indexof(tostring(asmt[7]), ":")),
    Severity=case(asmt[8] == 30, "High", asmt[8] == 20, "Medium", asmt[8] == 10, "Low", asmt[8] == 0, "Information", asmt[8] == 1, "Warning", asmt[8] == 2, "Critical", "Passed"),
    SeverityCode = toint(asmt[8]),
    Message=tostring(asmt[9])
| where Severity != "Passed"
| join kind = inner (
    machineAsmtInfo
) on machineId, SqlInstance, AsmtId
| distinct machineId, SqlInstance, Database, CheckId, SeverityCode, Severity, Message;
machineSummary
| summarize FailedServers = count_distinct(machineId), Issues = count() by SeverityCode, Severity, Alert = CheckId
| join kind = inner Rules on $left.Alert == $right.ID
| extend
    SqlDb = case(sqldb == 1, "Yes", "No"),
    SqlMi = case(sqlmi == 1, "Yes", "No"),
    SqlVm = case(sqlvm == 1, "Yes", "No")
| project Alert, SeverityCode, Severity, FailedServers, Issues, SqlDb, SqlMi, SqlVm, CategoryDescription, CategoryDetails, HelpLink = CategoryhelpLink
| order by SeverityCode desc, Alert asc
content.title: Alerts

content.query:
let Rules = datatable(
    ID: string,
    Category: string,
    sqlvm: string,
    sqldb: string,
    sqlmi: string,
    CategoryDescription: string,
    CategoryDetails: string,
    CategoryhelpLink: string
)

We recommend that full backups are turned on as per your RPO and RTO.

Category Description Details
A full database backup backs up the whole database. This includes part of the transaction log so that the full database can be recovered after a full database backup is restored. Full database backups represent the database at the time the backup finished.

Category Recommendation
Azure SQL Database and Azure SQL Managed Instance automated backups create:
 Full backups every week.
 Differential backups every 12 or 24 hours.
 Transaction log backups approximately every 10 minutes.

Reference Links
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/relational-databases/backup-restore/full-database-backups-sql-server?view=sql-server-ver16

These backups enable database restore to a specific point in time within the configured retention period, up to 35 days. However, if your data protection rules require that your backups be available for an extended time (up to 10 years). The storage for the backups are managed by Microsoft based on the customer defined retention policy.```,```Category Description

Category Description Details

"VLFCount","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost```,```Category Description
Update transaction log settings to reduce number of VLFs. 

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  The SQL Server Database Engine divides each physical log file internally into a number of virtual log files (VLFs). Virtual log files have no fixed size, and there is no fixed number of virtual log files for a physical log file. The Database Engine chooses the size of the virtual log files dynamically while it is creating or extending log files. The Database Engine tries to maintain a small number of virtual files. The size of the virtual files after a log file has been extended is the sum of the size of the existing log and the size of the new file increment. The size or number of virtual log files cannot be configured or set by administrators. If the log files grow to a large size in many small increments, they will have many virtual log files. This can slow down database startup and also log backup and restore operations. Conversely, if the log files are set to a large size with few or just one increment, they will have few very large virtual log files. We recommend that you assign log files a size value close to the final size required, using the required increments to achieve optimal VLF distribution, and also have a relatively large growth_increment value.

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Log backups and Instance startup are managed by Microsoft. The transaction logs are optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost.

Switch Server Plan to High Performance

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  In some cases you may experience degraded overall performance on a Windows Server 2008 R2 or later machine when running with the default (Balanced) power plan. The issue may occur irrespective of platform and may be exhibited on both native and virtual environments. The degraded performance may increase the average response time for some tasks and cause performance issues with CPU-intensive applications. Please note that you may not notice performance issues while performing simple operations. However, applications or scripts that intensively use resources (primarily processor and memory) may exhibit the problem. To work around the performance degradation issue, you can switch to the High Performance power plan.  However, this will disable dynamic performance scaling on the platform. Depending on the environment, if the platform is always under a heavy load, then this is a viable solution.

Set Query wait time 

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  Memory-intensive queries (such as those involving sorting and hashing) are queued when there is not enough memory available to run the query. The query wait option specifies the time, in seconds (from 0 through 2147483647), that a query waits for resources before it times out. The default value for this option is -1. This means the time-out is calculated as 25 times the estimated query cost.

Attempt to fetch a logical page failed. This error generally signifies page or allocation corruption, and often is caused by hardware or disk device driver failure.
Category Description Details
-  ERROR:  This error generally signifies page or allocation corruption in the specified database. SQL Server detects corruption when reading pages belonging to a table either by following the page linkages or by using the Index Allocation Map (IAM). All pages allocated to a table must belong to one of the allocation units associated with the table. If the allocation unit ID contained in the page header does not match an allocation unit ID associated with the table, this exception is raised. These errors are often caused by hardware or disk device driver failure.

```,```https://docs.microsoft.com/sql/relational-databases/statistics/statistics#CreateStatistics```,];
let machineCSV = ("{Server}");
let machineData = print machineCSV
| project machineArray = parse_csv(machineCSV)
| mv-expand machineId = machineArray
| project machineId = replace_string(tostring(machineId), "'", "")
| parse machineId with * 'machines/' Server
| where Server like "{ServerSearch}"
| join kind = inner (
    SqlAssessment_CL
    | extend
        machineId = tolower(_ResourceId),
        asmt = parse_csv(RawData),
        AsmtDate = format_datetime(TimeGenerated, 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm')
    | extend
        AsmtId=tostring(asmt[1]),
        SqlInstance = tostring(asmt[7])
    | where asmt[6] == "1"
    | distinct machineId, SqlInstance, AsmtDate, AsmtId
) on machineId
| project machineId, SqlInstance, AsmtDate, AsmtId;
let machineAsmtInfo = machineData
| join kind = inner (
    machineData
    | summarize AsmtDate = max(AsmtDate) by machineId, SqlInstance
) on machineId, SqlInstance, AsmtDate
| project machineId, SqlInstance, AsmtDate, AsmtId;
let machineSummary = SqlAssessment_CL
| extend
    machineId = tolower(_ResourceId),
    asmt = parse_csv(RawData)
| parse tostring(asmt[7]) with * ':' Database
| extend
    AsmtId=tostring(asmt[1]),
    CheckId=tostring(asmt[2]),
    SqlInstance = substring(tostring(asmt[7]), 0, indexof(tostring(asmt[7]), ":")),
    Severity=case(asmt[8] == 30, "High", asmt[8] == 20, "Medium", asmt[8] == 10, "Low", asmt[8] == 0, "Information", asmt[8] == 1, "Warning", asmt[8] == 2, "Critical", "Passed"),
    Message=tostring(asmt[9])
| where Severity != "Passed"
| where "{SevAlertsMig}" == "All" or CheckId == "{SevAlertsMig}"
| join kind = inner (
    machineAsmtInfo
) on machineId, SqlInstance, AsmtId
| join kind = inner Rules on $left.CheckId == $right.ID
| distinct machineId, SqlInstance, Database, CheckId, Severity, Message;
let highSevSummary = machineSummary
| where Severity == "High"
| summarize HighSevAlerts = count_distinct(CheckId), HighSevIssues = count() by machineId, SqlInstance;
machineSummary
| summarize DatabasesAssessed = count_distinct(Database), Alerts = count_distinct(CheckId), Issues = count() by machineId, SqlInstance
| join kind = leftouter (
    highSevSummary
) on machineId, SqlInstance
| summarize InstancesAssessed = count(), DatabasesAssessed = sum(DatabasesAssessed) - count(), Alerts = sum(Alerts), HighSevAlerts = sum(HighSevAlerts), Issues = sum(Issues), HighSevIssues = sum(HighSevIssues) by machineId
| order by machineId asc

We recommend that full backups are turned on as per your RPO and RTO.

Category Description Details
A full database backup backs up the whole database. This includes part of the transaction log so that the full database can be recovered after a full database backup is restored. Full database backups represent the database at the time the backup finished.

Category Recommendation

 Full backups every week.
 Differential backups every 12 or 24 hours.
 Transaction log backups approximately every 10 minutes.

However, if your data protection rules require that your backups be available for an extended time (up to 10 years). The storage for the backups are managed by Microsoft based on the customer defined retention policy.```,```Category Description

"VLFCount","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost```,```Category Description
Update transaction log settings to reduce number of VLFs. 

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  The SQL Server Database Engine divides each physical log file internally into a number of virtual log files (VLFs). Virtual log files have no fixed size, and there is no fixed number of virtual log files for a physical log file. The Database Engine chooses the size of the virtual log files dynamically while it is creating or extending log files. The Database Engine tries to maintain a small number of virtual files. The size of the virtual files after a log file has been extended is the sum of the size of the existing log and the size of the new file increment. The size or number of virtual log files cannot be configured or set by administrators. If the log files grow to a large size in many small increments, they will have many virtual log files. This can slow down database startup and also log backup and restore operations. Conversely, if the log files are set to a large size with few or just one increment, they will have few very large virtual log files. We recommend that you assign log files a size value close to the final size required, using the required increments to achieve optimal VLF distribution, and also have a relatively large growth_increment value.

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Log backups and Instance startup are managed by Microsoft. The transaction logs are optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost.

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  In some cases you may experience degraded overall performance on a Windows Server 2008 R2 or later machine when running with the default (Balanced) power plan. The issue may occur irrespective of platform and may be exhibited on both native and virtual environments. The degraded performance may increase the average response time for some tasks and cause performance issues with CPU-intensive applications. Please note that you may not notice performance issues while performing simple operations. However, applications or scripts that intensively use resources (primarily processor and memory) may exhibit the problem. To work around the performance degradation issue, you can switch to the High Performance power plan.  However, this will disable dynamic performance scaling on the platform. Depending on the environment, if the platform is always under a heavy load, then this is a viable solution.

Category recommendation

If this option is set to 1, SQL Server runs at a priority base of '13' scheduler. The default is '0', which is a priority base of '7'.

Category recommendation

"QueryWaitNotDefault","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Increasing query wait time is not recommended. The query wait time for SQL MI and SQL DB has been configured considering the potential impact of locks and deadlock. If there is query timeout because of resource constraints, we highly recommend tuning the query or scaling resources attached to the database.```,```Category Description
Set Query wait time 

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  Memory-intensive queries (such as those involving sorting and hashing) are queued when there is not enough memory available to run the query. The query wait option specifies the time, in seconds (from 0 through 2147483647), that a query waits for resources before it times out. The default value for this option is -1. This means the time-out is calculated as 25 times the estimated query cost.

Category recommendation

"ErrorLog605","Migration/Upgrade","0","0","0",```Minimum of three identical, consistent and synchronous copies of the disks are maintained in Azure. During disk corruption, the Azure SQL service will switch over to the healthy disk.```,```Category Description
Attempt to fetch a logical page failed. This error generally signifies page or allocation corruption, and often is caused by hardware or disk device driver failure.
Category Description Details
-  ERROR:  This error generally signifies page or allocation corruption in the specified database. SQL Server detects corruption when reading pages belonging to a table either by following the page linkages or by using the Index Allocation Map (IAM). All pages allocated to a table must belong to one of the allocation units associated with the table. If the allocation unit ID contained in the page header does not match an allocation unit ID associated with the table, this exception is raised. These errors are often caused by hardware or disk device driver failure. 

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Minimum of three identical, consistent and synchronous copies of the disks are maintained in Azure. During disk corruption, the Azure SQL service will switch over to the healthy disk.
   - Azure SQL VM - Minimum of three identical, consistent and synchronous copies of the disks are maintained in Azure. During disk corruption, the Azure VM will switch over to the healthy disk.

2.https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/disks-redundancy

"ErrorLog832","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Azure SQL PaaS is a scalable cloud database service that's always running on the patched OS with device drivers up to date. ```,```Category Description
A page that should have been constant has changed. This usually indicates a memory failure or other hardware or operating system corruption. An external factor has caused a database page to be modified outside the normal SQL Server engine code used to change database pages.

Category Description Details
-  ERROR:  An external factor has caused a database page to be modified outside the normal SQL Server engine code used to change database pages. 
The conditions could be:
- A thread running in the SQL Server process that incorrect writes on a database page. This is often referred to as a "scribbler"
- A hardware or operating system problem were the memory backing the database page is incorrect modified or damaged When SQL Server detects this behavior error 832 is raised.
Ensure all system drivers, Operating system updates, and hardware updates have been applied to our system.
Evaluate "external" DLLs loaded in SQL Server that could cause this problem including extended stored procedures, COM objects, or other DLLs that may be incorrectly modifying SQL Server memory reserved for database pages

 Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Azure SQL PaaS is a scalable cloud database service that's always running on the patched OS with device drivers up to date. Azure SQL DB and SQL MI does not support Extended Stored Procedures.

let sqlCSV = ("{SQLServer}");
let sqlData = print sqlCSV
| project sqlArray = parse_csv(sqlCSV)
| mv-expand sqlId = sqlArray
| project sqlId = replace_string(tostring(sqlId), "'", "")
| where "{machineIdMig}" != "None" 
| parse sqlId with * 'sqlserverinstances/' SQLServer
| parse "{machineIdMig}" with * 'machines/' Server
| where SQLServer startswith Server
| join kind = leftouter (
    SqlAssessment_CL
    | extend
        machineId = tolower(_ResourceId)
    | where machineId == "{machineIdMig}"
    | extend
        asmt = parse_csv(RawData),
        AsmtDate = format_datetime(TimeGenerated, 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm')
    | extend
        AsmtId=tostring(asmt[1]),
        SQLServer = replace_string(tolower(tostring(asmt[7])), "\\", "_")
    | where asmt[6] == "1"
    | distinct SQLServer, AsmtDate, AsmtId
) on SQLServer
| project sqlId, SQLServer, AsmtDate, AsmtId;
let sqlAsmtInfo = sqlData
| join kind = inner (
    sqlData
    | summarize Assessments = count(), EarliestAssessment = min(AsmtDate), LatestAssessment = max(AsmtDate) by sqlId, SQLServer
) on sqlId, SQLServer, $left.AsmtDate == $right.LatestAssessment
| project sqlId, SQLServer, Assessments, EarliestAssessment, LatestAssessment, AsmtId;
let sqlSummary = SqlAssessment_CL
| extend
    machineId = tolower(_ResourceId)
| where machineId == "{machineIdMig}"
| extend
    asmt = parse_csv(RawData)
| parse tolower(tostring(asmt[7])) with * ':' Database
| extend
    AsmtId=tostring(asmt[1]),
    CheckId=tostring(asmt[2]),
    SQLServer = replace_string(replace_string(tolower(tostring(asmt[7])), "\\", "_"), strcat(":", Database), ""),
    Severity=case(asmt[8] == 30, "High", asmt[8] == 20, "Medium", asmt[8] == 10, "Low", asmt[8] == 0, "Information", asmt[8] == 1, "Warning", asmt[8] == 2, "Critical", "Passed"),
    Message=tostring(asmt[9])
| where Severity != "Passed"
| where "{SevAlertsMig}" == "All" or CheckId == "{SevAlertsMig}"
| join kind = rightouter (
    sqlAsmtInfo
) on SQLServer, AsmtId
| join kind = leftouter Rules on $left.CheckId == $right.ID
| where CheckId == "" or ID != ""
| distinct sqlId, SQLServer, Database, CheckId, Severity, Message;
let highSevSummary = sqlSummary
| where Severity == "High"
| summarize HighSevAlerts = count_distinct(CheckId), HighSevIssues = count() by sqlId, SQLServer;
sqlSummary
| summarize DatabasesAssessed = count_distinct(Database), Alerts = count_distinct(CheckId), Issues = count() by sqlId, SQLServer
| join kind = leftouter (
    highSevSummary
) on SQLServer
| join kind = leftouter (
    sqlAsmtInfo
) on sqlId, SQLServer
| project
    sqlId
    , SQLServer
    , Assessments = case(isnull(Assessments), 0, Assessments)
    , EarliestAssessment
    , LatestAssessment
    , DatabasesAssessed = DatabasesAssessed - 1
    , Alerts = case(isnull(Assessments), 0, Alerts)
    , HighSevAlerts = case(isnull(HighSevAlerts), 0, HighSevAlerts)
    , Issues = case(isnull(Assessments), 0, Issues)
    , HighSevIssues = case(isnull(HighSevIssues), 0, HighSevIssues)
    , MigrationAssessment = sqlId
| order by sqlId asc
content.title: ARC Enabled SQL Server Instances

parameters.name: AssessmentDateMig
parameters.label: Assessment Date
parameters.query:
SqlAssessment_CL
| where tolower(_ResourceId) == "{machineIdMig}"
| extend asmt = parse_csv(RawData)
| where asmt[6] =~ "1"
| where replace_string(tolower(tostring(asmt[7])),"\\","_") == "{sqlNameMig}"
| project upload_id = tostring(asmt[1]),format_datetime(TimeGenerated, 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm')
| summarize TimeGenerated = min(TimeGenerated) by upload_id
| order by TimeGenerated

parameters.name: TargetMig
parameters.label: Target
parameters.query:
SqlAssessment_CL
| where _ResourceId == "{machineIdMig}"
| extend asmt = parse_csv(RawData)
| where replace_string(tolower(tostring(asmt[7])),"\\","_") contains "{sqlNameMig}"
| where tostring(asmt[1]) == "{AssessmentDateMig}"
| extend Severity=case(asmt[8] == 30, "High", asmt[8] == 20, "Medium", asmt[8] == 10, "Low", asmt[8] == 0, "Information", asmt[8] == 1, "Warning", asmt[8] == 2, "Critical", "Passed")
| extend Target=tostring(asmt[7])
| distinct TargetSearch = replace_string(replace_string(Target, "\\", "_"), ":", ""), Target
| order by Target asc

parameters.name: SeverityMig
parameters.label: Severity
parameters.query:
SqlAssessment_CL
| where _ResourceId == "{machineIdMig}"
| extend asmt = parse_csv(RawData)
| where replace_string(tolower(tostring(asmt[7])),"\\","_") contains "{sqlNameMig}"
| where tostring(asmt[1]) == "{AssessmentDateMig}"
| extend Severity=case(asmt[8] == 30, "High", asmt[8] == 20, "Medium", asmt[8] == 10, "Low", asmt[8] == 0, "Information", asmt[8] == 1, "Warning", asmt[8] == 2, "Critical", "Passed")
| extend SeverityCode = toint(asmt[8])
| distinct Severity, SeverityCode
| order by SeverityCode
| project-away SeverityCode

parameters.name: AlertMig
parameters.label: Alert
parameters.query:
SqlAssessment_CL
| where _ResourceId == "{machineIdMig}"
| extend asmt = parse_csv(RawData)
| where replace_string(tolower(tostring(asmt[7])),"\\","_") contains "{sqlNameMig}"
| where tostring(asmt[1]) == "{AssessmentDateMig}"
| extend Severity=case(asmt[8] == 30, "High", asmt[8] == 20, "Medium", asmt[8] == 10, "Low", asmt[8] == 0, "Information", asmt[8] == 1, "Warning", asmt[8] == 2, "Critical", "Passed")
| extend CheckId=tostring(asmt[2])
| distinct CheckId
| order by CheckId asc

We recommend that full backups are turned on as per your RPO and RTO.

Category Description Details
A full database backup backs up the whole database. This includes part of the transaction log so that the full database can be recovered after a full database backup is restored. Full database backups represent the database at the time the backup finished.

Category Recommendation
Azure SQL Database and Azure SQL Managed Instance automated backups create:
 Full backups every week.
 Differential backups every 12 or 24 hours.
 Transaction log backups approximately every 10 minutes.

Reference Links
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/relational-databases/backup-restore/full-database-backups-sql-server?view=sql-server-ver16

"OutdatedTranLogBackup","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Azure SQL PaaS provides completely managed and automated SQL Server database engine backups. These backups enable database restore to a specific point in time within the configured retention period, up to 35 days. However, if your data protection rules require that your backups be available for an extended time (up to 10 years). The storage for the backups are managed by Microsoft based on the customer defined retention policy.```,```Category Description
We recommend that transactional backups are turned on as per your RPO and RTO.

Category Description Details
Independent of the database backups, the database administrator backs up the transaction log at frequent intervals. For a given type of backup, the optimal interval depends on factors such as the importance of the data, the size of the database, and the workload of the server.

Category recommendation

 Full backups every week.

 Transaction log backups approximately every 10 minutes.

"VLFCount","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost```,```Category Description
Update transaction log settings to reduce number of VLFs. 

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  The SQL Server Database Engine divides each physical log file internally into a number of virtual log files (VLFs). Virtual log files have no fixed size, and there is no fixed number of virtual log files for a physical log file. The Database Engine chooses the size of the virtual log files dynamically while it is creating or extending log files. The Database Engine tries to maintain a small number of virtual files. The size of the virtual files after a log file has been extended is the sum of the size of the existing log and the size of the new file increment. The size or number of virtual log files cannot be configured or set by administrators. If the log files grow to a large size in many small increments, they will have many virtual log files. This can slow down database startup and also log backup and restore operations. Conversely, if the log files are set to a large size with few or just one increment, they will have few very large virtual log files. We recommend that you assign log files a size value close to the final size required, using the required increments to achieve optimal VLF distribution, and also have a relatively large growth_increment value.

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Log backups and Instance startup are managed by Microsoft. The transaction logs are optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost.

"PowerPlanSchemeNotRecommended","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost```,```Category Description
Switch Server Plan to High Performance

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  In some cases you may experience degraded overall performance on a Windows Server 2008 R2 or later machine when running with the default (Balanced) power plan. The issue may occur irrespective of platform and may be exhibited on both native and virtual environments. The degraded performance may increase the average response time for some tasks and cause performance issues with CPU-intensive applications. Please note that you may not notice performance issues while performing simple operations. However, applications or scripts that intensively use resources (primarily processor and memory) may exhibit the problem. To work around the performance degradation issue, you can switch to the High Performance power plan.  However, this will disable dynamic performance scaling on the platform. Depending on the environment, if the platform is always under a heavy load, then this is a viable solution.

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Azure SQL DB and MI are fully managed cloud services. The compute is optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost. No manual intervention needed

Set Query wait time 

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  Memory-intensive queries (such as those involving sorting and hashing) are queued when there is not enough memory available to run the query. The query wait option specifies the time, in seconds (from 0 through 2147483647), that a query waits for resources before it times out. The default value for this option is -1. This means the time-out is calculated as 25 times the estimated query cost.

Category recommendation

If there is query timeout because of resource constraints, we highly recommend tuning the query or scaling resources attached to the database.

"ErrorLog605","Migration/Upgrade","0","0","0",```Minimum of three identical, consistent and synchronous copies of the disks are maintained in Azure. During disk corruption, the Azure SQL service will switch over to the healthy disk.```,```Category Description
Attempt to fetch a logical page failed. This error generally signifies page or allocation corruption, and often is caused by hardware or disk device driver failure.
Category Description Details
-  ERROR:  This error generally signifies page or allocation corruption in the specified database. SQL Server detects corruption when reading pages belonging to a table either by following the page linkages or by using the Index Allocation Map (IAM). All pages allocated to a table must belong to one of the allocation units associated with the table. If the allocation unit ID contained in the page header does not match an allocation unit ID associated with the table, this exception is raised. These errors are often caused by hardware or disk device driver failure. 

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Minimum of three identical, consistent and synchronous copies of the disks are maintained in Azure. During disk corruption, the Azure SQL service will switch over to the healthy disk.

A page that should have been constant has changed. This usually indicates a memory failure or other hardware or operating system corruption. An external factor has caused a database page to be modified outside the normal SQL Server engine code used to change database pages.

Category Description Details
-  ERROR:  An external factor has caused a database page to be modified outside the normal SQL Server engine code used to change database pages. 
The conditions could be:
- A thread running in the SQL Server process that incorrect writes on a database page. This is often referred to as a "scribbler"
- A hardware or operating system problem were the memory backing the database page is incorrect modified or damaged When SQL Server detects this behavior error 832 is raised.
Ensure all system drivers, Operating system updates, and hardware updates have been applied to our system.
Evaluate "external" DLLs loaded in SQL Server that could cause this problem including extended stored procedures, COM objects, or other DLLs that may be incorrectly modifying SQL Server memory reserved for database pages

 Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Azure SQL PaaS is a scalable cloud database service that's always running on the patched OS with device drivers up to date. Azure SQL DB and SQL MI does not support Extended Stored Procedures.

```,```https://docs.microsoft.com/sql/relational-databases/statistics/statistics#CreateStatistics```,];
let allAlerts = SqlAssessment_CL
| where _ResourceId == "{machineIdMig}"
| extend asmt = parse_csv(RawData)
| where replace_string(tolower(tostring(asmt[7])),"\\","_") contains "{sqlNameMig}"
| extend
    AsmtId=tostring(asmt[1]),
    CheckId=tostring(asmt[2]),
    DisplayString=asmt[3],
    Description=tostring(asmt[4]),
    HelpLink=asmt[5],
    TargetType=case(asmt[6] == 1, "Server", asmt[6] == 2, "Database", ""),
    TargetName=tostring(asmt[7]), 
    Severity=case(asmt[8] == 30, "High", asmt[8] == 20, "Medium", asmt[8] == 10, "Low", asmt[8] == 0, "Information", asmt[8] == 1, "Warning", asmt[8] == 2, "Critical", "Passed"),
    Message=tostring(asmt[9]),
    TagsArr=split(tostring(asmt[10]), ","),
    SeverityCode = toint(asmt[8])
| where AsmtId == "{AssessmentDateMig}"
| where replace_string(replace_string(TargetName, "\\", "_"), ":", "") in ({TargetMig})
| where Severity in ({SeverityMig})
| where CheckId in ({AlertMig})
| join kind = inner Rules on $left.CheckId == $right.ID
| extend 
    sqldbfilter = case(sqldb == 1, "SqlDb", ""),
    sqlmifilter = case(sqldb == 1, "SqlMi", ""),
    sqlvmfilter = case(sqlvm == 1, "SqlVm", "")
| where sqldbfilter in ({PlatformMig}) or sqlmifilter in ({PlatformMig}) or sqlvmfilter in ({PlatformMig}) 
| distinct
    TargetType,
    TargetName,
    Severity,
    Message,
    Tags=strcat_array(array_slice(TagsArr, 1, -1), ', '),
    CheckId,
    Category,
    CategoryDescription,
    CategoryhelpLink,
    HelpLink = tostring(HelpLink),
    SeverityCode
| summarize Issues = count() by Severity, SeverityCode, Tags, CheckId, Category;
let failedAlerts = allAlerts
| where Severity != "Passed";
allAlerts
| join kind = leftouter (
    failedAlerts
  ) on CheckId
| where CheckId1 == "" or Severity != "Passed"
| summarize count() by Severity
| render piechart
content.title: Alerts by Severity

)

We recommend that full backups are turned on as per your RPO and RTO.

Category Description Details
A full database backup backs up the whole database. This includes part of the transaction log so that the full database can be recovered after a full database backup is restored. Full database backups represent the database at the time the backup finished.

Category Recommendation
Azure SQL Database and Azure SQL Managed Instance automated backups create:
 Full backups every week.
 Differential backups every 12 or 24 hours.
 Transaction log backups approximately every 10 minutes.

However, if your data protection rules require that your backups be available for an extended time (up to 10 years). The storage for the backups are managed by Microsoft based on the customer defined retention policy.```,```Category Description

-  Performance Optimization:  Keeping CPU usage rates within normal ranges is vital for servers hosting SQL Server instances. A continually high rate of CPU usage may indicate the need to upgrade the CPU or add multiple.

"VLFCount","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost```,```Category Description
Update transaction log settings to reduce number of VLFs. 

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  The SQL Server Database Engine divides each physical log file internally into a number of virtual log files (VLFs). Virtual log files have no fixed size, and there is no fixed number of virtual log files for a physical log file. The Database Engine chooses the size of the virtual log files dynamically while it is creating or extending log files. The Database Engine tries to maintain a small number of virtual files. The size of the virtual files after a log file has been extended is the sum of the size of the existing log and the size of the new file increment. The size or number of virtual log files cannot be configured or set by administrators. If the log files grow to a large size in many small increments, they will have many virtual log files. This can slow down database startup and also log backup and restore operations. Conversely, if the log files are set to a large size with few or just one increment, they will have few very large virtual log files. We recommend that you assign log files a size value close to the final size required, using the required increments to achieve optimal VLF distribution, and also have a relatively large growth_increment value.

Category recommendation

Switch Server Plan to High Performance

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  In some cases you may experience degraded overall performance on a Windows Server 2008 R2 or later machine when running with the default (Balanced) power plan. The issue may occur irrespective of platform and may be exhibited on both native and virtual environments. The degraded performance may increase the average response time for some tasks and cause performance issues with CPU-intensive applications. Please note that you may not notice performance issues while performing simple operations. However, applications or scripts that intensively use resources (primarily processor and memory) may exhibit the problem. To work around the performance degradation issue, you can switch to the High Performance power plan.  However, this will disable dynamic performance scaling on the platform. Depending on the environment, if the platform is always under a heavy load, then this is a viable solution.

If this option is set to 1, SQL Server runs at a priority base of '13' scheduler. The default is '0', which is a priority base of '7'.

"QueryWaitNotDefault","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Increasing query wait time is not recommended. The query wait time for SQL MI and SQL DB has been configured considering the potential impact of locks and deadlock. If there is query timeout because of resource constraints, we highly recommend tuning the query or scaling resources attached to the database.```,```Category Description
Set Query wait time 

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  Memory-intensive queries (such as those involving sorting and hashing) are queued when there is not enough memory available to run the query. The query wait option specifies the time, in seconds (from 0 through 2147483647), that a query waits for resources before it times out. The default value for this option is -1. This means the time-out is calculated as 25 times the estimated query cost.

"ErrorLog605","Migration/Upgrade","0","0","0",```Minimum of three identical, consistent and synchronous copies of the disks are maintained in Azure. During disk corruption, the Azure SQL service will switch over to the healthy disk.```,```Category Description
Attempt to fetch a logical page failed. This error generally signifies page or allocation corruption, and often is caused by hardware or disk device driver failure.
Category Description Details
-  ERROR:  This error generally signifies page or allocation corruption in the specified database. SQL Server detects corruption when reading pages belonging to a table either by following the page linkages or by using the Index Allocation Map (IAM). All pages allocated to a table must belong to one of the allocation units associated with the table. If the allocation unit ID contained in the page header does not match an allocation unit ID associated with the table, this exception is raised. These errors are often caused by hardware or disk device driver failure. 

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Minimum of three identical, consistent and synchronous copies of the disks are maintained in Azure. During disk corruption, the Azure SQL service will switch over to the healthy disk.
   - Azure SQL VM - Minimum of three identical, consistent and synchronous copies of the disks are maintained in Azure. During disk corruption, the Azure VM will switch over to the healthy disk.

A page that should have been constant has changed. This usually indicates a memory failure or other hardware or operating system corruption. An external factor has caused a database page to be modified outside the normal SQL Server engine code used to change database pages.

Category Description Details
-  ERROR:  An external factor has caused a database page to be modified outside the normal SQL Server engine code used to change database pages. 
The conditions could be:
- A thread running in the SQL Server process that incorrect writes on a database page. This is often referred to as a "scribbler"
- A hardware or operating system problem were the memory backing the database page is incorrect modified or damaged When SQL Server detects this behavior error 832 is raised.
Ensure all system drivers, Operating system updates, and hardware updates have been applied to our system.
Evaluate "external" DLLs loaded in SQL Server that could cause this problem including extended stored procedures, COM objects, or other DLLs that may be incorrectly modifying SQL Server memory reserved for database pages

 Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Azure SQL PaaS is a scalable cloud database service that's always running on the patched OS with device drivers up to date. Azure SQL DB and SQL MI does not support Extended Stored Procedures.

```,```https://docs.microsoft.com/sql/relational-databases/statistics/statistics#CreateStatistics```,];
SqlAssessment_CL
| where _ResourceId == "{machineIdMig}"
| extend asmt = parse_csv(RawData)
| where replace_string(tolower(tostring(asmt[7])),"\\","_") contains "{sqlNameMig}"
| extend
    AsmtId=tostring(asmt[1]),
    CheckId=tostring(asmt[2]),
    DisplayString=asmt[3],
    Description=tostring(asmt[4]),
    HelpLink=asmt[5],
    TargetType=case(asmt[6] == 1, "Server", asmt[6] == 2, "Database", ""),
    TargetName=tostring(asmt[7]), 
    Severity=case(asmt[8] == 30, "High", asmt[8] == 20, "Medium", asmt[8] == 10, "Low", asmt[8] == 0, "Information", asmt[8] == 1, "Warning", asmt[8] == 2, "Critical", "Passed"),
    Message=tostring(asmt[9]),
    TagsArr=split(tostring(asmt[10]), ","),
    SeverityCode = toint(asmt[8])
| where AsmtId == "{AssessmentDateMig}"
| where Severity != "Passed"
| where replace_string(replace_string(TargetName, "\\", "_"), ":", "") in ({TargetMig})
| where Severity in ({SeverityMig})
| where CheckId in ({AlertMig})
| join kind = inner Rules on $left.CheckId == $right.ID
| extend 
    sqldbfilter = case(sqldb == 1, "SqlDb", ""),
    sqlmifilter = case(sqldb == 1, "SqlMi", ""),
    sqlvmfilter = case(sqlvm == 1, "SqlVm", "")
| where sqldbfilter in ({PlatformMig}) or sqlmifilter in ({PlatformMig}) or sqlvmfilter in ({PlatformMig}) 
| distinct
    TargetType,
    TargetName,
    Severity,
    Message,
    Tags=strcat_array(array_slice(TagsArr, 1, -1), ', '),
    CheckId,
    SqlDb = case(sqldb == 1, "Yes", "No"),
    SqlMi = case(sqlmi == 1, "Yes", "No"),
    SqlVm = case(sqlvm == 1, "Yes", "No"),
    Category,
    CategoryDescription,
    CategoryDetails,
    CategoryhelpLink,
    HelpLink = tostring(HelpLink),
    SeverityCode
| summarize Issues = count() by Alert = CheckId, Severity, SeverityCode, SqlDb, SqlMi, SqlVm, CategoryDescription, CategoryDetails, HelpLink = CategoryhelpLink
| project Alert, Severity, SeverityCode, Issues, SqlDb, SqlMi, SqlVm, CategoryDescription, CategoryDetails, HelpLink
| order by SeverityCode, Issues
| project-away SeverityCode
content.title: Recommendations Summary

)

We recommend that full backups are turned on as per your RPO and RTO.

Category Description Details
A full database backup backs up the whole database. This includes part of the transaction log so that the full database can be recovered after a full database backup is restored. Full database backups represent the database at the time the backup finished.

Category Recommendation
Azure SQL Database and Azure SQL Managed Instance automated backups create:
 Full backups every week.
 Differential backups every 12 or 24 hours.
 Transaction log backups approximately every 10 minutes.

Reference Links

These backups enable database restore to a specific point in time within the configured retention period, up to 35 days. However, if your data protection rules require that your backups be available for an extended time (up to 10 years). The storage for the backups are managed by Microsoft based on the customer defined retention policy.```,```Category Description

Update transaction log settings to reduce number of VLFs. 

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  The SQL Server Database Engine divides each physical log file internally into a number of virtual log files (VLFs). Virtual log files have no fixed size, and there is no fixed number of virtual log files for a physical log file. The Database Engine chooses the size of the virtual log files dynamically while it is creating or extending log files. The Database Engine tries to maintain a small number of virtual files. The size of the virtual files after a log file has been extended is the sum of the size of the existing log and the size of the new file increment. The size or number of virtual log files cannot be configured or set by administrators. If the log files grow to a large size in many small increments, they will have many virtual log files. This can slow down database startup and also log backup and restore operations. Conversely, if the log files are set to a large size with few or just one increment, they will have few very large virtual log files. We recommend that you assign log files a size value close to the final size required, using the required increments to achieve optimal VLF distribution, and also have a relatively large growth_increment value.

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Log backups and Instance startup are managed by Microsoft. The transaction logs are optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost.

Switch Server Plan to High Performance

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  In some cases you may experience degraded overall performance on a Windows Server 2008 R2 or later machine when running with the default (Balanced) power plan. The issue may occur irrespective of platform and may be exhibited on both native and virtual environments. The degraded performance may increase the average response time for some tasks and cause performance issues with CPU-intensive applications. Please note that you may not notice performance issues while performing simple operations. However, applications or scripts that intensively use resources (primarily processor and memory) may exhibit the problem. To work around the performance degradation issue, you can switch to the High Performance power plan.  However, this will disable dynamic performance scaling on the platform. Depending on the environment, if the platform is always under a heavy load, then this is a viable solution.

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Azure SQL DB and MI are fully managed cloud services. The compute is optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost. No manual intervention needed

Set Query wait time 

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  Memory-intensive queries (such as those involving sorting and hashing) are queued when there is not enough memory available to run the query. The query wait option specifies the time, in seconds (from 0 through 2147483647), that a query waits for resources before it times out. The default value for this option is -1. This means the time-out is calculated as 25 times the estimated query cost.

Category recommendation

"ErrorLog605","Migration/Upgrade","0","0","0",```Minimum of three identical, consistent and synchronous copies of the disks are maintained in Azure. During disk corruption, the Azure SQL service will switch over to the healthy disk.```,```Category Description
Attempt to fetch a logical page failed. This error generally signifies page or allocation corruption, and often is caused by hardware or disk device driver failure.
Category Description Details
-  ERROR:  This error generally signifies page or allocation corruption in the specified database. SQL Server detects corruption when reading pages belonging to a table either by following the page linkages or by using the Index Allocation Map (IAM). All pages allocated to a table must belong to one of the allocation units associated with the table. If the allocation unit ID contained in the page header does not match an allocation unit ID associated with the table, this exception is raised. These errors are often caused by hardware or disk device driver failure. 

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Minimum of three identical, consistent and synchronous copies of the disks are maintained in Azure. During disk corruption, the Azure SQL service will switch over to the healthy disk.
   - Azure SQL VM - Minimum of three identical, consistent and synchronous copies of the disks are maintained in Azure. During disk corruption, the Azure VM will switch over to the healthy disk.

"ErrorLog832","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Azure SQL PaaS is a scalable cloud database service that's always running on the patched OS with device drivers up to date. ```,```Category Description
A page that should have been constant has changed. This usually indicates a memory failure or other hardware or operating system corruption. An external factor has caused a database page to be modified outside the normal SQL Server engine code used to change database pages.

Category Description Details
-  ERROR:  An external factor has caused a database page to be modified outside the normal SQL Server engine code used to change database pages. 
The conditions could be:
- A thread running in the SQL Server process that incorrect writes on a database page. This is often referred to as a "scribbler"
- A hardware or operating system problem were the memory backing the database page is incorrect modified or damaged When SQL Server detects this behavior error 832 is raised.
Ensure all system drivers, Operating system updates, and hardware updates have been applied to our system.
Evaluate "external" DLLs loaded in SQL Server that could cause this problem including extended stored procedures, COM objects, or other DLLs that may be incorrectly modifying SQL Server memory reserved for database pages

 Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Azure SQL PaaS is a scalable cloud database service that's always running on the patched OS with device drivers up to date. Azure SQL DB and SQL MI does not support Extended Stored Procedures.

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB - >  32-GB size per core  has been assigned for every database.
  -  Azure SQL MI- -> 24-GB size per vCore for entire GP tier and limited by instance size on BC tier.By default, Azure SQL Managed Instance creates 12 tempdb data files, and 1 tempdb log file, but it's possible to modify this configuration.
  - Azure SQL VM  -  Offers while configuring to place the data, log, and tempdb files on separate drives.
     For the data drive, use premium P30 and P40 or smaller disks to ensure the availability of cache support. When using the Ebdsv5 VM series, use Premium SSD v2 which provides better price-performance for workloads that require high IOPS and I/O throughput

```,```https://docs.microsoft.com/sql/relational-databases/statistics/statistics#CreateStatistics```,];
let platform_types = dynamic(["total", "sqldb", "sqlmi", "sqlvm"]);
SqlAssessment_CL
| where _ResourceId == "{machineIdMig}"
| extend asmt = parse_csv(RawData)
| where replace_string(tolower(tostring(asmt[7])),"\\","_") contains "{sqlNameMig}"
| extend
    AsmtId=tostring(asmt[1]),
    CheckId=tostring(asmt[2]),
    DisplayString=asmt[3],
    Description=tostring(asmt[4]),
    HelpLink=asmt[5],
    TargetType=case(asmt[6] == 1, "Server", asmt[6] == 2, "Database", ""),
    TargetName=tostring(asmt[7]), 
    Severity=case(asmt[8] == 30, "High", asmt[8] == 20, "Medium", asmt[8] == 10, "Low", asmt[8] == 0, "Information", asmt[8] == 1, "Warning", asmt[8] == 2, "Critical", "Passed"),
    Message=tostring(asmt[9]),
    TagsArr=split(tostring(asmt[10]), ","),
    SeverityCode = toint(asmt[8])
| where AsmtId == "{AssessmentDateMig}"
| where Severity != "Passed"
| where replace_string(replace_string(TargetName, "\\", "_"), ":", "") in ({TargetMig})
| where Severity in ({SeverityMig})
| where CheckId in ({AlertMig})
| where "{selAlertMig}" == "All" or CheckId == "{selAlertMig}"
| join kind = inner Rules on $left.CheckId == $right.ID
| extend 
    sqldbfilter = case(sqldb == 1, "SqlDb", ""),
    sqlmifilter = case(sqldb == 1, "SqlMi", ""),
    sqlvmfilter = case(sqlvm == 1, "SqlVm", "")
| where sqldbfilter in ({PlatformMig}) or sqlmifilter in ({PlatformMig}) or sqlvmfilter in ({PlatformMig}) 
| distinct
    TargetType,
    TargetName,
    Severity,
    Message,
    Tags=strcat_array(array_slice(TagsArr, 1, -1), ', '),
    CheckId,
    sqldb = toint(sqldb),
    sqlmi = toint(sqlmi),
    sqlvm = toint(sqlvm),
    Category,
    CategoryDescription,
    CategoryhelpLink,
    HelpLink = tostring(HelpLink),
    SeverityCode
| summarize total = count(), sqldb = sum(sqldb), sqlmi = sum(sqlmi), sqlvm = sum(sqlvm)
| project properties = pack_all()
| mv-apply platform_type = platform_types to typeof(string) on (
    project platform_type, recommendation_count = toint(properties[platform_type])
  )
| project-away properties
| render barchart

We recommend that full backups are turned on as per your RPO and RTO.

Category Description Details
A full database backup backs up the whole database. This includes part of the transaction log so that the full database can be recovered after a full database backup is restored. Full database backups represent the database at the time the backup finished.

Category Recommendation
Azure SQL Database and Azure SQL Managed Instance automated backups create:
 Full backups every week.
 Differential backups every 12 or 24 hours.
 Transaction log backups approximately every 10 minutes.

Reference Links
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/relational-databases/backup-restore/full-database-backups-sql-server?view=sql-server-ver16
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/automated-backups-overview?view=azuresql```,```https://docs.microsoft.com/sql/relational-databases/statistics/statistics#CreateStatistics```,
"OutdatedTranLogBackup","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Azure SQL PaaS provides completely managed and automated SQL Server database engine backups. These backups enable database restore to a specific point in time within the configured retention period, up to 35 days. However, if your data protection rules require that your backups be available for an extended time (up to 10 years). The storage for the backups are managed by Microsoft based on the customer defined retention policy.```,```Category Description

High CPU Usage on Server

Category recommendation

"VLFCount","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost```,```Category Description
Update transaction log settings to reduce number of VLFs. 

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  The SQL Server Database Engine divides each physical log file internally into a number of virtual log files (VLFs). Virtual log files have no fixed size, and there is no fixed number of virtual log files for a physical log file. The Database Engine chooses the size of the virtual log files dynamically while it is creating or extending log files. The Database Engine tries to maintain a small number of virtual files. The size of the virtual files after a log file has been extended is the sum of the size of the existing log and the size of the new file increment. The size or number of virtual log files cannot be configured or set by administrators. If the log files grow to a large size in many small increments, they will have many virtual log files. This can slow down database startup and also log backup and restore operations. Conversely, if the log files are set to a large size with few or just one increment, they will have few very large virtual log files. We recommend that you assign log files a size value close to the final size required, using the required increments to achieve optimal VLF distribution, and also have a relatively large growth_increment value.

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Log backups and Instance startup are managed by Microsoft. The transaction logs are optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost.

"PowerPlanSchemeNotRecommended","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost```,```Category Description
Switch Server Plan to High Performance

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  In some cases you may experience degraded overall performance on a Windows Server 2008 R2 or later machine when running with the default (Balanced) power plan. The issue may occur irrespective of platform and may be exhibited on both native and virtual environments. The degraded performance may increase the average response time for some tasks and cause performance issues with CPU-intensive applications. Please note that you may not notice performance issues while performing simple operations. However, applications or scripts that intensively use resources (primarily processor and memory) may exhibit the problem. To work around the performance degradation issue, you can switch to the High Performance power plan.  However, this will disable dynamic performance scaling on the platform. Depending on the environment, if the platform is always under a heavy load, then this is a viable solution.

Category recommendation

Set Priority Boost option to default value

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  The 'priority boost' option used to specify whether Microsoft SQL Server should run at a higher scheduling priority than other processes on the same computer. If this option is set to 1, SQL Server runs at a priority base of '13' scheduler. The default is '0', which is a priority base of '7'.

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Azure SQL DB and MI are fully managed cloud services. The compute configurations are optimized and Managed by Microsoft for both SQL MI and Azure SQL DB considering performance and cost. No manual intervention needed

"QueryWaitNotDefault","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Increasing query wait time is not recommended. The query wait time for SQL MI and SQL DB has been configured considering the potential impact of locks and deadlock. If there is query timeout because of resource constraints, we highly recommend tuning the query or scaling resources attached to the database.```,```Category Description
Set Query wait time 

Category Description Details
-  Performance Optimization:  Memory-intensive queries (such as those involving sorting and hashing) are queued when there is not enough memory available to run the query. The query wait option specifies the time, in seconds (from 0 through 2147483647), that a query waits for resources before it times out. The default value for this option is -1. This means the time-out is calculated as 25 times the estimated query cost.

Category recommendation

If there is query timeout because of resource constraints, we highly recommend tuning the query or scaling resources attached to the database.

To optimize storage performance, plan for highest uncached IOPS available and use data caching as a performance feature for data reads while avoiding virtual machine and disks capping.

Database IOPs and throughput for the data file and the transaction log files for different service tiers has been clearly documented.    - Azure VM - Increasing virtual disk column count improves the disk's performance. The number of disks in the pool is the maximum available number of columns.

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Azure SQL DB / Managed Instance is a fully managed service that's always running the latest version of SQL. Azure SQL DBMI has been optimized for performance. Database IOPs and throughput for the data file and the transaction log files for different service tiers has been clearly documented. Tools like DMA, Azure Data Studio or Azure Migrate can help size the for Azure SQL DB/MI to meet the performance.
   - Azure VM - Standard HDDs and SSDs have varying latencies and bandwidth and are only recommended for dev/test workloads. Production workloads should use premium Managed Disks on Azure.
Reference Links

Category recommendation

   - Azure VM - Place the tempDB files on the local ephemeral disks or Premium SSD's. Use Performance metrics or monitoring tools to estimate the IOPS and throughput requirements for the tempDB files

"ErrorLog605","Migration/Upgrade","0","0","0",```Minimum of three identical, consistent and synchronous copies of the disks are maintained in Azure. During disk corruption, the Azure SQL service will switch over to the healthy disk.```,```Category Description
Attempt to fetch a logical page failed. This error generally signifies page or allocation corruption, and often is caused by hardware or disk device driver failure.
Category Description Details
-  ERROR:  This error generally signifies page or allocation corruption in the specified database. SQL Server detects corruption when reading pages belonging to a table either by following the page linkages or by using the Index Allocation Map (IAM). All pages allocated to a table must belong to one of the allocation units associated with the table. If the allocation unit ID contained in the page header does not match an allocation unit ID associated with the table, this exception is raised. These errors are often caused by hardware or disk device driver failure. 

Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Minimum of three identical, consistent and synchronous copies of the disks are maintained in Azure. During disk corruption, the Azure SQL service will switch over to the healthy disk.
   - Azure SQL VM - Minimum of three identical, consistent and synchronous copies of the disks are maintained in Azure. During disk corruption, the Azure VM will switch over to the healthy disk.
Reference Links

2.https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/disks-redundancy

"ErrorLog832","Migration/Upgrade","0","1","1",```Azure SQL PaaS is a scalable cloud database service that's always running on the patched OS with device drivers up to date. ```,```Category Description
A page that should have been constant has changed. This usually indicates a memory failure or other hardware or operating system corruption. An external factor has caused a database page to be modified outside the normal SQL Server engine code used to change database pages.

Category Description Details
-  ERROR:  An external factor has caused a database page to be modified outside the normal SQL Server engine code used to change database pages. 
The conditions could be:
- A thread running in the SQL Server process that incorrect writes on a database page. This is often referred to as a "scribbler"
- A hardware or operating system problem were the memory backing the database page is incorrect modified or damaged When SQL Server detects this behavior error 832 is raised.
Ensure all system drivers, Operating system updates, and hardware updates have been applied to our system.
Evaluate "external" DLLs loaded in SQL Server that could cause this problem including extended stored procedures, COM objects, or other DLLs that may be incorrectly modifying SQL Server memory reserved for database pages

 Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Azure SQL PaaS is a scalable cloud database service that's always running on the patched OS with device drivers up to date. Azure SQL DB and SQL MI does not support Extended Stored Procedures.

Thread resources are low in the server.
Category Description Details
-  ERROR:  The query processor could not start the necessary thread resources for parallel query execution.
 Category recommendation
   - Azure SQL DB/MI - Azure SQL Database and Azure SQL Managed Instance enable you to dynamically add more resources to your database with minimal downtime
Azure SQL Database offers the ability to dynamically scale your databases:With a single database, you can use either DTU or vCore models to define maximum amount of resources that will be assigned to each database.
Elastic pools enable you to define maximum resource limit per group of databases in the pool.
Azure SQL Managed Instance allows you to scale as well:SQL Managed Instance uses vCores mode and enables you to define maximum CPU cores and maximum of storage allocated to your instance. All databases within the managed instance will share the resources allocated to the instance.

```,```https://docs.microsoft.com/sql/relational-databases/statistics/statistics#CreateStatistics```,];
SqlAssessment_CL
| where _ResourceId == "{machineIdMig}"
| extend asmt = parse_csv(RawData)
| where replace_string(tolower(tostring(asmt[7])),"\\","_") contains "{sqlNameMig}"
| extend
    AsmtId=tostring(asmt[1]),
    CheckId=tostring(asmt[2]),
    DisplayString=asmt[3],
    Description=tostring(asmt[4]),
    HelpLink=asmt[5],
    TargetType=case(asmt[6] == 1, "Server", asmt[6] == 2, "Database", ""),
    TargetName=tostring(asmt[7]), 
    Severity=case(asmt[8] == 30, "High", asmt[8] == 20, "Medium", asmt[8] == 10, "Low", asmt[8] == 0, "Information", asmt[8] == 1, "Warning", asmt[8] == 2, "Critical", "Passed"),
    Message=tostring(asmt[9]),
    TagsArr=split(tostring(asmt[10]), ","),
    SeverityCode = toint(asmt[8])
| where AsmtId == "{AssessmentDateMig}"
| where Severity != "Passed"
| where replace_string(replace_string(TargetName, "\\", "_"), ":", "") in ({TargetMig})
| where Severity in ({SeverityMig})
| where CheckId in ({AlertMig})
| where "{selAlertMig}" == "All" or CheckId == "{selAlertMig}"
| join kind = inner Rules on $left.CheckId == $right.ID
| extend 
    sqldbfilter = case(sqldb == 1, "SqlDb", ""),
    sqlmifilter = case(sqldb == 1, "SqlMi", ""),
    sqlvmfilter = case(sqlvm == 1, "SqlVm", "")
| where sqldbfilter in ({PlatformMig}) or sqlmifilter in ({PlatformMig}) or sqlvmfilter in ({PlatformMig}) 
| distinct
    Target = TargetType,
    Name = TargetName,
    Severity,
    Message,
    Tags=strcat_array(array_slice(TagsArr, 1, -1), ', '),
    Alert = CheckId,
    SqlDb = case(sqldb == 1, "Yes", "No"),
    SqlMi = case(sqlmi == 1, "Yes", "No"),
    SqlVm = case(sqlvm == 1, "Yes", "No"),
    Description,
    HelpLink = tostring(HelpLink),
    SeverityCode
| order by SeverityCode desc, Target desc, Name asc
| project-away SeverityCode
